dialogue_line_replacements.text: Estoy un poco cansado. Es que trabajo demasiado.
dialogue_line_replacements.translation: I'm a bit tired. It's because I work too much.

dialogue_line_replacements.text: Sí, soy casado. Mi mujer es médica — es muy inteligente.
dialogue_line_replacements.translation: Yes, I'm married. My wife is a doctor — she's very intelligent.

cultural_notes_overrides.formality: In Spain, 'mi mujer' (my woman/wife) is the standard informal term for wife — not 'mi esposa' as in Latin America. Both are correct but 'mujer' dominates casual speech in Spain.
cultural_notes_overrides.gestures: Spaniards use 'bueno...' (well...) as a filler before using estar for hesitant states — 'Bueno, estoy más o menos' (Well, I'm so-so). This filler signals a nuanced answer coming.
cultural_notes_overrides.regional_variations: In Spain, 'estar' + past participle is often preferred for states: 'estoy hecho polvo' (I'm exhausted, literally 'I'm turned to dust'). The key ser/estar contrast is the same across all dialects — the rule doesn't change.
cultural_notes_overrides.distincion: 'Estar' has no /θ/ issue. But ser conjugations: 'sois' [ˈsojθ] is the Spain vosotros form — not used in Latin America. This is the most dialect-specific ser/estar form.
